Problem:
A complex function \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\) evolves over time under the influence of a linear differential operator \\( L \\), where \\( Lz = \\frac{dz}{dt} = Az + B \\) and both A and B are complex matrices. The system is further analyzed using the Laplace transform, defined by \\( \\mathcal{L}\\{z(t)\\}(s) = \\int_0^\\infty e^{-st}z(t) \\, dt \\).

If we examine the system at t = 0 with initial condition \\( z(0) = z_0 \\) and allow it to evolve according to \\( L \\) without any other intervention, will the Laplace transform of \\( z(t) \\) be affected by changing the matrix B?
Explanation: Changing the matrix B directly alters the differential equation, thus modifying the evolution of \\( z(t) \\). Since the Laplace transform integrates this evolving function over time, any changes in B affect the entire form of \\( \\mathcal{L}\\{z(t)\\}(s) \\).
